awd_titl_txt: A Biochemical, Proteomic and Functional Delineation of Dcbld1 and 2 Signaling during Zebrafish Neural Retina Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Even though proper vision is important to all types of animals, how the parts of the eyes that communicate with the brain (the retinas) develop is only partly understood. The present research project is conducted in zebrafish because of advantageous genetic and experimental tools available for studying early eye development. Previous studies carried out by this research team found two proteins that need to function properly for retinas to develop (called DCBLD1 and DCBLD2); if these proteins aren't made, retinas don't form properly.  Replacing a defective fish DBCLD2 protein with a human DCBLD2 protein enables the fish retina to develop normally, suggesting that DCBLD proteins function in a similar manner in all animals with backbones. The present project will examine the mechanisms by which DCBLD proteins govern proper retina formation using a combination of anatomical, biochemical, cell biological, functional genetic and proteomic techniques, and will provide a more complete understanding of retina formation.  Broader impacts of this research include laboratory training for high school students, university undergraduates, graduate students, and staff scientists in many modern experimental approaches. Several of the students will be specifically recruited from populations that are underrepresented in science. The research and training will be conducted by an inter-disciplinary team in Vermont (the University of Vermont and Norwich University), Massachusetts (Boston College) and Puerto Rico (the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras and the Metropolitan University).

Previous work by the principal investigators determined that the putative neuronal guidance receptors DCBLD1 and 2 act as scaffolds for the Crk family of adaptors, which are known to play important roles in the positioning of neurons during development. Histological studies in transgenic zebrafish identified Dcbld1 and 2 as essential for both proper retinal ganglion cell development and proper positioning and/or differentiation of retinal cell types. Human DCBLD2 was shown to rescue dcbld2 morphant phenotypes. The following research aims will be conducted to delineate the roles of Dcbld1 and 2 in zebrafish eye development: Aim1 will use immunohistochemistry to determine how loss of Dcbld1 and 2 affects cell proliferation and the differentiation of zebrafish retinal cell types. Aim 2 will use functional developmental approaches to determine if the DCBLD1 and 2 tyrosine phosphorylation sites required for Crk/CrkL binding are essential for the development of the zebrafish retina. Aim 3 will use biochemical, proteomic, cell biological and functional genetic approaches to characterize the phosphorylation of DCBLD proteins, DCBLD binding partners and the roles these play in zebrafish neural retina development.

por.por_cntn:
ABSTRACT

As embryos develop, their cells increase in number and ultimately specialize to create the array of different tissues in a fully developed organism. The specialization occurs in part through intricate molecular interactions within and between cells. These interactions are chiefly driven by proteins which are made by only specific cells at specific times during development. The principal investigators have identified that two related proteins (Dcbld1 and Dcbld2) play critical roles in eye development, but how they participate in eye development isn?t understood. Given that these proteins span the cellular membrane and are thus connected to both the extracellular and intracellular environments, it is hypothesized that they can receive cues in the extracellular environment to communicate to proteins on the intracellular side. This enables these proteins to carry signals from the outside to the inside to effectuate proper eye development. Zebrafish embryos will be used for the proposed organismal studies because zebrafish embryos are readily accessible in high numbers, are transparent and allow examination of eye development in real time. Further, eye development in the zebrafish is very similar to eye in all vertebrates including humans. Additionally, the principal investigators have used the human versions of the Dcbld proteins to correct loss of the zebrafish Dcbld proteins. Finally, genetic modification of zebrafish is relatively straightforward, and many zebrafish subtypes have been generated with specific cell types labeled with different colors in the zebrafish which allows for tracking the generation of and spatial location of different cell types during development of the eye. For determining molecular mechanisms of Dcbld proteins occurring inside cells the investigators will used cultured cells and biochemical analyses including protein mass spectrometry. Impacts beyond the acquiring data to increase our understanding of eye development will include: (i) enhancement and research and teaching for undergraduate and graduate students at Norwich University, Boston College and the University of Puerto Rico, (ii) provide opportunities for high school students from Puerto Rico at the University of Vermont, and (iii) provide training and research support for the proteomics core and researchers at the University of Puerto Rico.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Intellectual Merit: DCBLD1 and 2 comprise a family of vertebrate-specific transmembrane signaling molecules with poorly characterized functions. Research based on this award in the laboratories of the principal investigators have led to several important findings regarding these proteins and the genes that encode them. dcbld1 and dcbld2 are important for proper zebrafish eye development and integrity of the optic nerve head. DCBLD1 and 2 transduce their signals by becoming phosphorylated by the non-receptor tyrosine kinases Fyn and Abl and by receptor tyrosine kinases. Tyrosine phosphorylation of DCBLD1 and 2 alters their interactomes including inducing the binding of CRK and CRKL adaptor proteins. Zebrafish mutant in crk and crkl also exhibit defects in eye development, showing smaller eye size, reduced integrity of the optic nerve head, and improper retinal lamination in 50 percent of embryos which are homozygous mutant in both genes. The compensatory mechanism is hypothesized to be due to the related adaptor proteins from the NCK family. The interactomes of both CRK and CRKL and NCK proteins show common binding partners to their critical and homologous functional domains. Collectively five publications resulted from research based on this award, with two additional publications through collaborations. One other article has been submitted and three are in preparation. One Ph.D. dissertation, two M.S. theses, and ten honors theses were completed based on research from this award. Two forthcoming Ph.D. dissertations and one M.S. thesis will include results generated from this award. Research based on this award was presented at national (with international attendance), regional and local venues in the form of poster and oral presentations, including at one regional conference focused on research by under-represented minority groups.

Broader impacts: Four faculty members from three institutions (University of Vermont, Norwich University, and Boston College) trained 7 Ph.D. students, two M.S students, twenty-three undergraduates and three high school students. Graduating students have moved on to stage-appropriate positions in undergraduate programs, graduate programs, postdocs, or the private sector. Proteomics Staff at the University of Puerto Rico, as well as many researchers and students (over 100) were trained in proteomics via seminars and hands-on workshops.
